solutions.title: clear-easy-sql-step-by-step-correct-formatting-comprehensive-explanation
solutions.content:
# ❗ Upvote ⬆ if you found this useful ✔

MySQL solution for **585. Investments in 2016** Problem. 

![image.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/4b1d3937-b51e-403e-a9b5-6bf85aae0979_1694014177.0987067.png)


# 💡 Intuition (hint)

This problem is harder to understand than to solved. Can be conquered with CTEs or subqueries and simple filters using WHERE. 

# 🎯 Approach (solution)

In this solution we will use three-level query. 

Going from the lowest level, we have two subqueries that are used later to search for *pid* that meets both conditions. 

**Query 1** - simple query that finds all *tiv_2015* that occur more than once in the table (are not unique)
```sql
SELECT tiv_2015
FROM Insurance
GROUP BY tiv_2015
HAVING COUNT(tiv_2015) > 1
```

**Query 2** - simple query that finds all combination of *lat* and *con* that occur exactly once in the table (are unique).
CONCAT is used to combine both *lat* and *con* into one field. 
```sql
SELECT CONCAT(lat, '+', lon)
FROM Insurance
GROUP BY CONCAT(lat, '+', lon)
HAVING COUNT(CONCAT(lat, '+', lon)) = 1
```

The **middle query** consists of a query that looks for *pid* that meets 2 conditions:
1. *tiv_2015* is present in list of non-unique *tiv_2015*
2. *CONCAT(lat, '+', lon)* is present in list of unique *CONCAT(lat, '+', lon)*
```sql
    SELECT pid
    FROM Insurance
    WHERE 
        tiv_2015 IN (**Query 1**)
        AND CONCAT(lat, '+', lon) IN (**Query 2**)
```

The highest level query just calculates the SUM of all *tiv_2016* for all *pid* that are filtered in the **middle query**
```sql
SELECT ROUND(SUM(tiv_2016), 2) AS tiv_2016
FROM Insurance
WHERE pid IN (**middle query**)
```
# 📈 Complexity

- ⏱ Time complexity:
Beats 76% of solutions with MySQL (at the time of submission)

- 💾 Space complexity:
Beats 100% of solutions with MySQL (space complexity in case of this problem is constant for all solutions)

# 🔥 Code

```sql
SELECT ROUND(SUM(tiv_2016), 2) AS tiv_2016
FROM Insurance
WHERE pid IN (
    SELECT pid
    FROM Insurance
    WHERE 
        tiv_2015 IN (
            SELECT tiv_2015
            FROM Insurance
            GROUP BY tiv_2015
            HAVING COUNT(tiv_2015) > 1
    )
        AND CONCAT(lat, '+', lon) IN (
            SELECT CONCAT(lat, '+', lon)
            FROM Insurance
            GROUP BY CONCAT(lat, '+', lon)
            HAVING COUNT(CONCAT(lat, '+', lon)) = 1
    )
);
```

solutions.title: solution-if-you-forgot-pandas-functions
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Storing whether condition is met or not in an Array on N size 

# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def find_investments(insurance: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    tiv = insurance["tiv_2015"]
    n = len(tiv)
    condition1 = [False]*n
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(n):
            if(i!=j and tiv[i]==tiv[j]):
                condition1[i]=True
    
    condition2 = [True]*n
    location = []
    i=0
    print(n)
    for i in range(n):
        location.append(str(insurance["lat"][i]) + "|" + str(insurance["lon"][i]))

    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(n):
            if(i!=j and location[i]==location[j]):
                condition2[i]=False
    
    insurance["condition1"]=condition1
    insurance["condition2"]=condition2

    result = []
    result.append(insurance[(insurance["condition1"] == True) & (insurance["condition2"] == True)]["tiv_2016"].sum())
    print(result)
    return pd.DataFrame(result,columns = ["tiv_2016"])
    
```

solutions.title: oracle-solution
solutions.content:
# Intuition
In my case I had to create two subqueries, since it looks like mostly simple to understand.

# Approach
1) Find unique locations described in "subq1"
2) Find not unique TIVs, to filter it descripted in "subq2". By the way, without "subq2" in test case will be PASS, however in Submit you'll get error in Case 1
3) Inner join subq1-2 and get sum

# Code
```
select round(sum(i.tiv_2016), 2) as tiv_2016
from Insurance i
         join (select lat || '.' || lon merged
               from Insurance
               group by lat || '.' || lon
               having count(lat || '.' || lon) = 1) subq1
                        on i.lat || '.' || i.lon = subq1.merged
         join (select tiv_2015
               from Insurance
               group by tiv_2015
               having count(tiv_2015) != 1) subq2
                        on i.tiv_2015 = subq2.tiv_2015
```

solutions.title: solution-using-ctes
solutions.content:
# Approach
1. Find out pid of unique city based on`lat`, `lon`.
2. Find out pid whose`tiv_2015` is same.
3. Inner join both CTEs based on pids and then add the `tiv_2016`

# Code
```
# Write your MySQL query statement below

With UniqueCity As
(
        Select pid, tiv_2016
        From Insurance
        Group by lat,lon
        Having count(lat) = 1 and count(lon) = 1
),

Sametiv as
(
        Select distinct i1.pid
        From Insurance as i1
        Inner join Insurance as i2
        on i1.pid != i2.pid
        Where i1.tiv_2015 = i2.tiv_2015
        order by i1.pid

solutions.title: mysql-solution-using-ctes
solutions.content:
# Approach
* Find the unique lat and lon combinations.
* Find shared tiv_2015 instances.
* Join them to the main table for filtering.

# Code
```
WITH lat_lon AS(
    SELECT CONCAT(lat, lon) AS place FROM Insurance
),
uniq_places AS (
    SELECT
        place,
        COUNT(place) AS place_count
    FROM lat_lon
    GROUP BY 1
    HAVING place_count = 1
),
shared_tiv_2015 AS (
    SELECT
        tiv_2015,
        COUNT(tiv_2015) AS tiv2015_count
    FROM Insurance
    GROUP BY 1
    HAVING tiv2015_count > 1
)
SELECT ROUND(SUM(i.tiv_2016), 2) AS tiv_2016
FROM Insurance AS i
JOIN uniq_places AS u on u.place = CONCAT(i.lat, i.lon)
JOIN shared_tiv_2015 USING (tiv_2015);
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
The result of the below code:
```
select a.pid, b.pid from Insurance a inner join Insurance b on (a.lat,a.lon) = (b.lat,b.lon)
where a.pid<>b.pid
```
is:
```
| pid | pid |
| --- | --- |
| 1   | 1   |
| 3   | 2   |
| 2   | 2   |
| 3   | 3   |
| 2   | 3   |
| 4   | 4   |
```
So when filtering the `where a.pid<>b.pid`, we get the policyholder who has the unique location.

solutions.title: pandas-4-lines-with-explanation
solutions.content:
# Intuition

Consists of 4 lines:
 1. Get pids based on two statements
 2. Filter based on them
 3. Get sum and round

# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def find_investments(df: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
  id1 = df.drop_duplicates(subset=['lat','lon'], keep=False).pid
  id2 = df.loc[df.duplicated(subset='tiv_2015', keep=False)].pid
  df = df.loc[df.pid.isin(id1) & df.pid.isin(id2)]
  return df[['tiv_2016']].sum().to_frame('tiv_2016').round(2)
```

solutions.title: very-simple-solution-with-minimal-code-with-explanation
solutions.content:
# Intuition

These approach emphasizes achieving **performance with minimal code**.

Please **Upvote** if you find helpful.

# Approach

The step by step explanation based on the code is:

1. The outermost query selects the **rounded sum of tiv_2016 values** as tiv_2016.

2. The **WHERE clause filters rows** based on two conditions:

    - The **first condition** checks if the tiv_2015 value of a policyholder exists in a subquery's result. 
    The subquery finds tiv_2015 values that occur more than once in the Insurance table, indicating that multiple policyholders share the same tiv_2015 value.

    - The **second condition** checks if the combination of latitude (lat) and longitude (lon) values exists in another subquery's result.
    The subquery groups rows by lat and lon and selects groups that have a count of 1. This means that these groups represent unique (lat, lon) pairs, indicating that the policyholders in these groups are located in the unique location.

3. By combining these two conditions, the query identifies policyholders who have the same tiv_2015 value as one or more others (first condition) and are not located in the same city as any other policyholder (second condition).

4. Finally, the query calculates the sum of tiv_2016 values for the selected policyholders, rounds the result to two decimal places, and returns it as tiv_2016.

# Code
```
SELECT ROUND(SUM(tiv_2016), 2) as tiv_2016
FROM Insurance
WHERE tiv_2015 IN
(
  SELECT tiv_2015
  FROM Insurance
  GROUP BY tiv_2015
  HAVING COUNT(*) > 1
)
AND (lat, lon) IN
(
  SELECT lat, lon
  FROM Insurance
  GROUP BY lat, lon
  HAVING COUNT(*) = 1
)
```

  HAVING COUNT(*) = 1
)
```

solutions.title: simple-easy-to-understand-mysql-solution
solutions.content:
# Approach
* Create cte1 to find all records with COUNT(tiv_2015)>1
* Create cte2 to find Unique pairs of lat, lon

The problem does not require creation of cte1 and cte2 as both can be incoporated into the main query itself.
I have created the ctes for simplicity and better understanding.

# Complexity
- Time complexity: Beats 94.6%
- Space complexity: Beats 100%

# Code
```
WITH cte1 AS(
    SELECT DISTINCT 
        tiv_2015
    FROM Insurance
    GROUP BY tiv_2015
    HAVING COUNT(tiv_2015)>1
),

cte2 AS (
    SELECT 
        lat, lon
    FROM Insurance
    GROUP BY lat, lon
    HAVING COUNT(lat)=1 OR COUNT(lon)=1
)

SELECT 
    ROUND(SUM(tiv_2016), 2) AS tiv_2016
FROM Insurance
WHERE 
    tiv_2015 IN (SELECT tiv_2015 FROM cte1) AND
    lat IN (SELECT lat FROM cte2) AND
    lon IN (SELECT lon FROM cte2)
```

where a.lat != b.lat and a.lon != b.lon and a.tiv_2015 = b.tiv_2015 
group by a.tiv_2016
)
and (aa.lon, aa.lat)  in (
  select lon, lat from Insurance
  group by lon, lat
  having count(*) = 1
)

```

solutions.title: easy-solution-with-cte-and-subquery
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
We have two critaria, so pid should not be in same city. we have to manage it and then we check wheather invest value have to be same with one or more policyholder.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
1. We take out same city policyholders, so that we exclude that pid.
2. Then we have to check value of tiv_2015 should be same with one or more policyholder so we do left join for comparsion but to easy our work, we can use that t2.pid not equal to t1.pid so that we don't to compare with the same raw.
3. Now just exclude loaction in this table from cte, we use not in for excluding because we can have more then one resulting row.
4. Now sum of tic_2016 with round with 2 decimal.

# Code
```
# Write your MySQL query statement below
with cte as (
    select concat(lat,',',lon) as location
    from Insurance
    group by lat, lon
    having count(pid)>1
),

cte2 as (
    select distinct i1.*
    from Insurance i1
    left join Insurance i2
    on i1.tiv_2015=i2.tiv_2015
    where i1.pid<>i2.pid
    and concat(i1.lat,',',i1.lon) not in (
        select location from cte
    )
)

select round(sum(tiv_2016), 2) as tiv_2016
from cte2
```

solutions.title: pandas-intuitive-one-line
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
There are two conditions to check, based on the number of occurrences of certain values in the table. If we include the count of these values as new columns, it is easy to filter for the desired conditions.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
In order to add the extra columns with the counts we use the built-in ```value_counts()``` and merge.

# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def find_investments(insurance: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    return pd.DataFrame({
        'tiv_2016': [
        insurance.merge(
            insurance['tiv_2015'].value_counts().rename('tiv_2015_count'),
            left_on='tiv_2015',
            right_index=True,
            how='left'
        ).merge(
            insurance[['lat','lon']].value_counts().rename('city_count'),
            left_on=['lat', 'lon'],
            right_index=True,
            how='left'
        ).query(
            'tiv_2015_count >= 2 & city_count == 1'
        )[
            'tiv_2016'
        ].sum()]
    })


```

solutions.title: pandas-solution-4-lines
solutions.content:
# idea
mask both condition and filter at the same time 


# Code
```
import pandas as pd

def find_investments(insurance: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    
    # have the same tiv_2015 value as one or more other policyholders
    cond1 = (insurance.duplicated(subset=['tiv_2015'], keep=False))
    
     #are not located in the same city as any other policyholder 
     #(i.e., the (lat, lon) attribute pairs must be unique)
    cond2 =  ~(insurance.duplicated(subset=['lat','lon'], keep=False))
    # both conditions       
    insurance = insurance[cond1 & cond2]
    
    
    return  pd.DataFrame({"tiv_2016":[insurance['tiv_2016'].sum().round(2)]})
```

import pandas as pd

def find_investments(insurance: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    
    # have the same tiv_2015 value as one or more other policyholders
    cond1 = (insurance.duplicated(subset=['tiv_2015'], keep=False))
    
     #are not located in the same city as any other policyholder 
     #(i.e., the (lat, lon) attribute pairs must be unique)
    cond2 =  ~(insurance.duplicated(subset=['lat','lon'], keep=False))
    # both conditions       
    insurance = insurance[cond1 & cond2]
    
    
    return  pd.DataFrame({"tiv_2016":[insurance['tiv_2016'].sum().round(2)]})
```

solutions.title: simplest-solution-subquery-neatcode
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
We need sum of only those tiv_2016 that meet these two conditions:
1. The corresponding tiv_2015 should not be unique.
2. The corresponding (lat,lon) pair should be unique
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
For uniqueness in (lat,lon) pair, we use Group By & COUNT(*) = 1 in a subquery.
For Non-uniqueness in tiv_2015, we use Group By & COUNT(*) > 1 in a subquery.

# Code
```
SELECT
    ROUND(SUM(tiv_2016),2) AS tiv_2016
FROM
    Insurance
WHERE
    (lat,lon) IN (SELECT lat,lon FROM Insurance GROUP BY 1,2 HAVING COUNT(*) = 1)
AND
    tiv_2015 IN (SELECT tiv_2015 FROM Insurance GROUP BY 1 HAVING COUNT(*) > 1)
```

AND
    tiv_2015 IN (SELECT tiv_2015 FROM Insurance GROUP BY 1 HAVING COUNT(*) > 1)
```

solutions.title: simplest-solution-cte-join-neatcode
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
We need sum of only those tiv_2016 that meet these two conditions:
1. The corresponding tiv_2015 should not be unique.
2. The corresponding (lat,lon) pair should be unique
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
We write two CTEs each for tiv and location.
For uniqueness in (lat,lon) pair, we use Group By & COUNT(*) = 1.
For Non-uniqueness in tiv_2015, we use Group By & COUNT(*) > 1.
Then Join these CTEs with the Insurance Table.

---
> *Consider Upvote, if you like the solution.*
---


# Code
```
WITH CTE_loc AS
(
    SELECT 
        lat, lon 
    FROM 
        Insurance 
    GROUP BY
        lat, lon 
    HAVING 
        COUNT(*) = 1
),

CTE_tiv AS
(
    SELECT 
        tiv_2015 
    FROM 
        Insurance 
    GROUP BY 
        tiv_2015 
    HAVING 
        COUNT(*) > 1
)

SELECT
    ROUND(SUM(i.tiv_2016), 2) AS tiv_2016
FROM
    Insurance AS i
JOIN
    CTE_tiv AS t ON i.tiv_2015 = t.tiv_2015
JOIN
    CTE_loc AS l ON i.lat = l.lat AND i.lon = l.lon;

```

```

select sum(a.TIV_2016) as TIV_2016 from insurance a
where 
a.TIV_2015 in (select b.TIV_2015 from insurance b where a.PID <> b.PID)
and 
(a.LAT, a.LON) not in (select c.LAT, c.LON from insurance c where a.PID <> c.PID)
;

WITH tiv AS (
    SELECT tiv_2015, tiv_2016
    FROM Insurance 
    GROUP BY CONCAT(lat,lon)
    HAVING COUNT(\*)= 1
),
tiv_sum AS (
    SELECT tiv_2015, SUM(tiv_2016) AS tiv_2016
    FROM tiv
    GROUP BY tiv_2015
    HAVING COUNT(\*) >= 2
)

)

)

AND (LONG=1 OR LATI=1)

By applying the concatenation of both of them, something that you did on the second solution with the `partition by`, you would be able to count each of them and remove duplicated values. why you use concat in here, you can just couple it in parentheses

    select tiv_2015
    from insurance
    group by tiv_2015
    having count(*) >1
)
and (lat,lon) in (
    select lat, lon
    from insurance 
    group by lat,lon

)

with cte as 
(select pid, TIV_2015, TIV_2016, count(concat(lat, lon)) over (partition by concat(lat, lon))as cnt1, count(TIV_2015) over(partition by tiv_2015) as cnt
from insurance)

select sum(TIV_2016) as TIV_2016 from cte where cnt1=1 and cnt!=1

Would really appreciate if someone could help me understand what's the deal here, and/or guided to some sort of documentation on this stuff. PLEASE NOTE: LEETCODE DOES NOT HAVE SUCH AN ISSUE, IT'S JUST ABOUT MY LOCAL SERVER. Code in question: `SELECT i1.pid AS pid` ` FROM Insurance AS i1` ` INNER JOIN Insurance AS i2` ` ON i1.lat = i2.lat AND i1.lon = i2.lon AND i1.pid != i2.pid;` `ClassicSession.run_sql: Insufficient number of values for placeholders in query` I feel like what's really going on here, is SQL has trouble linking all of the fields, as exactly same issue arised once I separated one of the conditions into consequent WHERE statement: `SELECT i1.pid AS pid` `FROM Insurance AS i1` `INNER JOIN Insurance AS i2` `ON i1.lat = i2.lat AND i1.lon = i2.lon` `WHERE i1.pid != i2.pid;` `ClassicSession.run_sql: Insufficient number of values for placeholders in query` Once again, would appreciate any help.

"""select sum(tiv_2016) as tiv_2016 from insurance where 
lat || lon in (select lat || lon
from insurance
group by lat || lon
having count(*) = 1)
and tiv_2015 in (select tiv_2015 from insurance group by tiv_2015 having count(*) > 1)"""

# Write your MySQL query statement below
select sum(a.TIV_2016) as TIV_2016 from insurance a
where 
a.TIV_2015 in (select b.TIV_2015 from insurance b where a.PID <> b.PID)
and 
(a.LAT, a.LON) not in (select c.LAT, c.LON from insurance c where a.PID <> c.PID)
;

WITH tiv AS (
    SELECT tiv_2015, tiv_2016
    FROM Insurance 
    GROUP BY CONCAT(lat,lon)
    HAVING COUNT(\*)= 1
),
tiv_sum AS (
    SELECT tiv_2015, SUM(tiv_2016) AS tiv_2016
    FROM tiv
    GROUP BY tiv_2015
    HAVING COUNT(\*) >= 2
)

SELECT ROUND(SUM(tiv_2016),2) AS tiv_2016
FROM tiv_sum


can anyone tell me why this isn't working

SELECT ROUND(SUM(a.TIV_2016), 2) AS TIV_2016
FROM insurance a
WHERE EXISTS (
    SELECT 1
    FROM insurance b
    WHERE a.PID <> b.PID AND a.TIV_2015 = b.TIV_2015
)
AND NOT EXISTS (
    SELECT 1
    FROM insurance c
    WHERE a.PID <> c.PID AND (a.LAT = c.LAT AND a.LON = c.LON)
)

Could anyone explain what's wrong with this solution? 

WITH CTE AS (SELECT TIV_2016 AS AD, COUNT(LAT) OVER (PARTITION BY LON) AS LONG, COUNT(LON) OVER (PARTITION BY LAT) AS LATI, COUNT (PID) OVER (PARTITION BY TIV_2015) AS TIV FROM INSURANCE)
SELECT ROUND(SUM(AD)*1.00,2) AS tiv_2016
FROM CTE
WHERE TIV>1
AND (LONG=1 OR LATI=1)

Above solution doesn't work but when I changed it to the one below it works fine.

WITH CTE AS (SELECT TIV_2016 AS AD, COUNT(LAT) OVER (PARTITION BY LON,lat) AS LONG, COUNT (PID) OVER (PARTITION BY TIV_2015) AS TIV FROM INSURANCE)
SELECT ROUND(SUM(AD)*1.00,2) AS tiv_2016
FROM CTE
WHERE TIV>1
AND LONG=1

I can explain , on your first solution you has been taking the columns of `lat & lon` as separeted values, there are more like a composite key that you need to concatenate to have the real value and know/understand on which cases are they really being duplicated. By applying the concatenation of both of them, something that you did on the second solution with the `partition by`, you would be able to count each of them and remove duplicated values. The `TIV` columns you got it right

# Write your MySQL query statement below
select round(sum(TIV_2016),2) as TIV_2016 from insurance
where TIV_2015 in
(select TIV_2015 from insurance group by TIV_2015 having count(TIV_2015) >1)
and concat(LAT, LON) not in
(select concat(LAT, LON) from insurance group by LAT, LON having count(concat(LAT, LON)) >1)

why you use concat in here, you can just couple it in parentheses

# Write your MySQL query statement below

select round(sum(tiv_2016),2) as tiv_2016
from insurance 
where tiv_2015 in (
    select tiv_2015
    from insurance
    group by tiv_2015
    having count(*) >1
)
and (lat,lon) in (
    select lat, lon
    from insurance 
    group by lat,lon
    having count(*) = 1
)
wtf

with cte as 
(select pid, TIV_2015, TIV_2016, count(concat(lat, lon)) over (partition by concat(lat, lon))as cnt1, count(TIV_2015) over(partition by tiv_2015) as cnt
from insurance)

select sum(TIV_2016) as TIV_2016 from cte where cnt1=1 and cnt!=1
